results.statement: Why Optimizing IV Chemotherapy Matters. Cancer ranks among the top 3 causes of death in Asia.
results.reference: Khetan AK, Palileo-Villanueva LM, Mat-Nasir N, et al. Mortality, cardiovascular disease, and their associations with risk factors in Southeast Asia. JACC Asia. 2024;4(8):624-633. doi:10.1016/j.jaca- si.2024.05.008

- 1.Khetan AK.pdf: A total of 2,226 (11%) members of the cohort died during a follow-up period of a mean of 8.2 ±
4.0 years. | The mortality rate was 13.7 (95% CI: 13.1-14.2) per 1,000 person-years. | The most
common cause of mortality was CVD (38% of mortality), followed by cancer (12%), respiratory
diseases (10.5%), infection (8.7%), and injury (4.4%) (Figure 1).

results.statement: Why Optimizing IV Chemotherapy Matters. Intravenous (IV) chemotherapy is a key treatment modality in oncology care, offering rapid drug delivery and a systemic response, making it crucial for cancer patients.
results.matched_evidence: - 3.Duggan C, 2024.pdf: Systemic anti-cancer therapy (SACT) has evolved over the past 20 years.|The majority of SACT is delivered intravenously.|Therefore, the insertion of a vascular access device (VAD) is a prerequisite (Kim 2021).

results.statement: Patient-Centric Challenges in IV Chemotherapy. Difficult Intravenous Access (DIVA) - Difficult Intravenous Access (DIVA) refers to the challenge of securing IV access due to two or more failed attempts using traditional techniques, absence of visible or palpable veins, or a known history of DIVA.
results.matched_evidence: No matching reference PDF was found for the extraction: 5

results.statement: Patient-Centric Challenges in IV Chemotherapy. One of the major contributing factors to DIVA is the frequent cannulation attempts for IV chemotherapy administration, which often results in venous depletion, compromising vein integrity and making future cannulation more difficult.

results.statement: Patient-Centric Challenges in IV Chemotherapy. Increased pain impacts patient experience
results.matched_evidence: - 13.Sou2017.pdf: Patients with DiVA may undergo multiple, painful at-tempts to gain peripheral venous access [7]. | This can have deleterious effects on patient care that include missed medication doses, signifi-cant pain and increased anxiety as well as increased risk of premature device failure [17, 20, 21]. | Patients reported a much higher level of pain with can-nulation attempts prior to referral for ultrasound guid-ance, some experienced severe pain with nearly a quarter (23.3%) of patients reporting a pain score of 10/10. | This significant finding illustrates the impact of needle pain which can cause anxiety, phobia and significantly reduce patient satisfaction with the health care facility [21].

results.statement: Occupational Hazards to HCPs in IV Chemotherapy. Exposure may occur at any point in the journey of a hazardous drug.
results.matched_evidence:
- 16.Nyman,2007.pdf: Health care workers who prepare and administer antineoplastic agents risk exposure to these drugs.
- 17.Wick,2003.pdf: Abstract: Surface contamination with and personnel exposure to antineoplastic agents before and after the implementation of a closed-system protective device were studied.

results.statement: Hazardous Drug (HD) Contamination Check. A study of six hospitals found that frequently contacted surfaces at every stage of the hospital medication system had measurable levels of antineoplastic drug contamination.
results.matched_evidence: - 27.Hon CY,2013.pdf: Our study found that frequently contacted surfaces at every stage of the hospital medication system had measureable levels of antineoplastic drug contamination.

results.statement: Occupational Hazards to HCPs in IV Chemotherapy. Despite advances in oncology care, vascular access and administration of hazardous drugs continue to pose challenges for healthcare professionals, including oncology nurses, vascular access specialists, pharmacists, oncologists, quality and safety officers involved in VAD and IV chemotherapy care.
results.matched_evidence:
- 18. ISOPP.pdf: Since the initial release of the International Society of
Oncology Pharmacy Practitioners (ISOPP) Standards for
the Safe Handling of Cytotoxic Drugs in 2007, much has
evolved in oncology pharmacy. |Safe handling practices
have been refined and new hazardous agents have been dis-
covered and developed for treatment to pose new chal-
lenges for workers caring for their patients.
- 19.Abu-Alhaija D,2023.pdf: Exposure to chemotherapy is an occupational hazard predisposing nurses to severe health effects.|The serious health effects of exposure to chemotherapy on nurses and other healthcare professionals are well documented and include genotoxicity (Bouraoui et al., 2011), frequent miscarriages, infertility, congenital abnormalities (Connor et al., 2014), and the increased the risk to develop cancer (NIOSH, 2016).
results.page_location: Page 2, Introduction | Page 1, Background section | Page 2, Background section

results.statement: Occupational Hazards to HCPs in IV Chemotherapy. The risks of handling hazardous drugs are real and significant:
results.matched_evidence:
- 18. ISOPP.pdf: Occupational exposure to hazardous drugs and the potential
health risk to healthcare workers first became a recognised
safety concern in the 1970s.|Working with hazardous drugs in health care settings may
cause skin rashes, has been associated with infertility, mis-
carriage and birth defects, and raises concerns about the
possible development of leukemia or other cancers.

results.statement: Occupational Hazards to HCPs in IV Chemotherapy. Detrimental effect on DNA - Staff handling HD show up to a 5x increase in certain chromosomal aberrations.
results.matched_evidence:
- 20.Cavallo,2005.pdf: Our CA analysis showed in exposed groups a significant increase (about 2.5-fold) of structural chromosomal aberrations, with a particular relevance for breaks (up to 5.0-fold) confirming the study of Burgaz et al. [23] who also found an increase of the CA frequency in a group of 26 nurses handling antineoplastic drugs.
- 21. Mcdiarmid,2010.pdf: The highly exposed group, however, when compared with the nonexposed has a general trend of higher abnormality frequencies for almost every outcome examined, reaching statistical significance with excesses in structural abnormalities of chromosome 5 (0.02 vs 0.18; P = 0.04 for the nonexposed vs the highly exposed, respectively) and total changes in chromosome 5 (0.04 vs 0.29; P = 0.01).|Table 6 was constructed in a similar fashion as was Table 5 but using only alkylating agent handling events as the exposure measure.|At 100 handling events (corresponding to the top nine exposed participants), the IRRs observed for each type of abnormality for chromosomes 5 or 7 or both are 2- to 3-fold higher than those shown in Table 5 derived from the effect of any drug-handling event.
results.page_location: Page 5, Discussion section | Page 3, Results section | Page 5, Results section

results.statement: Occupational Hazards to HCPs in IV Chemotherapy. Increased risk of cancer development - Increased relative risk of leukemia for oncology nurses, 2.8x increase in non-melanoma cancer, and 3.7x increase in non-Hodgkin's lymphoma in pharmacy techs.
results.matched_evidence:
- 22.Skov T, 1992.pdf: The relative risk (RR) for leukaemia was significantly increased (10.65) but based on only two cases, one of acute myeloblastic and one of chronic myeloid leukaemia.|We have carried out a study of leukaemia and non-Hodgkin's lymphoma among physicians who have worked with ADs." The RR for leukaemia was 2-85 (95% CI 0-51-16-02).
- 23.Hansen J,1994.pdf: An increased risk for non-Hodgkin's lymphoma appeared among long-term pharmacy dispensers (N = 5, SIR 3.7, 95% CI 1.2-8.9).
results.page_location: Page 1, Abstract | Page 3, Paragraph 6 | Page 2, Results section

results.statement: Occupational Hazards to HCPs in IV Chemotherapy. Damage to internal organs - Three consecutive nurses handling cytostatic agents had liver damage.
results.reference: Sotaniemi EA, Sutinen S, Arranto AJ, et al. Liver damage in nurses handling cytostatic agents. Acta Med Scand. 1983;214(3):181-189. 25.Lawson CC, Rocheleau CM, Whelan EA, et al. Occupational exposures among nurses and risk of spontaneous abortion. Am J Obstet Gynecol. 2012;206(4):327.e1-327.e8. 26.Hemminki K, Kyronen P, Lindbohm ML. Spontaneous abortions and malformations in the offspring of nurses exposed to anaesthetic gases, cytostatic drugs, and other potential hazards in hospitals. J Epidemiol Community Health. 1985;39(2):141-147. 27.Hon CY, Teschke K, Chu W, Demers P, Venners S. Antineoplastic drug contamination of surfaces throughout the hospital medication system in Canadian hospitals. J Occup Environ Hyg. 2013;10(7):374-383. doi:10.1080/15459624.2013.789743
results.matched_evidence: - 24.Sotaniemi EA,1983.pdf: Three consecutive head nurses developed liver injury after years of handling cytostatic drugs.

results.statement: Occupational Hazards to HCPs in IV Chemotherapy. Reproductive issues - 2x greater risk of miscarriage among staff handling antineoplastic drugs.
results.matched_evidence: - 25.Lawson CC, 2012.pdf: After adjusting for age, parity, shift work, and hours worked, antineoplastic drug exposure was associated with a 2-fold increased risk of spontaneous abortion, particularly with early spontaneous abortion before the 12th week, and 3.5-fold increased risk among nulliparous women.

results.statement: Hazardous Drug (HD) Contamination Check. A NIOSH survey of 1,954 healthcare professionals revealed that they touched other work surfaces while wearing chemotherapy gloves:
results.reference: Boiano JM, Steege AL, Sweeney MH. Adherence to safe handling guidelines by health care workers who administer antineoplastic drugs. J Occup Environ Hyg. 2014;11(11):728-740. 31.United States Pharmaco- peial Convention. USP General Chapter <800> Hazardous Drugs—Handling in Healthcare Settings. Published February 1, 2016. Updated 2022. Accessed August 5, 2025. https://www.usp.org/compounding/gener- al-chapter-hazardous-drugs-handling-healthcare
results.matched_evidence: - 30 .Boiano JM,2015.pdf: Respondents were asked if they performed specific activities while wearing gloves that had been used to administer antineoplastic drugs. The most common activity reported by 6 of every 10 respondents was “touch I.V. pump or bed controls.” Other reported activities included: “touch waste basket,” “use pens/pencils,” “touch door knobs, cabinets, or drawers,” “use computer or calculator," "handle files or charts,” among others (Table VI).
results.page_location: Page 27, Glove Use: Activities Where Cross-Contamination May Occur (Done While Wearing Gloves That Were Used While Administering Antineoplastic Drugs)
